articles.headline: As ISIS Posts in Portuguese, U.S. and Brazil Bolster Olympics Security
articles.snippet: Jihadists calling for mayhem at the Olympics — and Brazil’s relative inexperience in grappling with terrorism — has led to a sense of urgency in Rio.
articles.abstract: Jihadists calling for mayhem at the Olympics — and Brazil’s relative inexperience in grappling with terrorism — has led to a sense of urgency in Rio.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Worried about possible terrorist attacks at the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil’s government is working closely with American law enforcement and intelligence services to identify threats and thwart potential disasters at the Games.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Under Pressure, Big Banks Vie for Instant Payment Market
articles.snippet: Wells Fargo joined three other banks in allowing instant payments, a market that has been taken over by services like Apple Pay and PayPal’s Venmo.
articles.abstract: Wells Fargo joined three other banks in allowing instant payments, a market that has been taken over by services like Apple Pay and PayPal’s Venmo.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this digital age when almost anything can be had in an instant, the movement of money can seem glaringly slow.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Theranos, Embattled Laboratory, Shifts to Medical Machines
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Holmes, chief executive, introduced technology called the miniLab, suggesting a new business model for the embattled blood-testing company.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Holmes, chief executive, introduced technology called the miniLab, suggesting a new business model for the embattled blood-testing company.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Elizabeth Holmes tried to salvage the reputation of her embattled blood-testing company here on Monday, discussing its technology and data at a scientific meeting for the first time. Instead of focusing on sins of the past, she made promises for the future.

articles.headline: Why Corporate America Is Leaving the Suburbs for the City
articles.snippet: Companies including McDonald’s and General Electric are moving headquarters to cities like Boston and Chicago, partly as a lure to younger employees.
articles.abstract: Companies including McDonald’s and General Electric are moving headquarters to cities like Boston and Chicago, partly as a lure to younger employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — For decades, many of the nation’s biggest companies staked their futures far from the fraying downtowns of aging East Coast and Midwestern cities. One after another, they decamped for sprawling campuses in the suburbs and exurbs.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Draft Deferments: Four for College, One for Bad Feet
articles.snippet: With Mr. Trump accused by a dead soldier’s father of having never “sacrificed,” his medical deferment during the Vietnam era is facing new scrutiny.
articles.abstract: With Mr. Trump accused by a dead soldier’s father of having never “sacrificed,” his medical deferment during the Vietnam era is facing new scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in 1968, at the age of 22, Donald J. Trump seemed the picture of health.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Dave Philipps

articles.headline: Even Uber Couldn’t Bridge the China Divide
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing company joins the top tech giants in failing to overcome the enormous and varied barriers to competing effectively in China.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing company joins the top tech giants in failing to overcome the enormous and varied barriers to competing effectively in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick, the co-founder and chief executive of the ride-hailing giant Uber, often defended his eagerness to risk billions on winning the Chinese market with a simple question: If you have a chance to become Amazon and Alibaba at the same time, why not try?

articles.headline: The Activist and Herbalife: Just Maybe Ackman’s Right
articles.snippet: Bill Ackman worked for years to drive the supplement company out of business, calling it a pyramid scheme. It’s still in business, but maybe not for long.
articles.abstract: Bill Ackman worked for years to drive the supplement company out of business, calling it a pyramid scheme. It’s still in business, but maybe not for long.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Ackman, the activist investor, has been painted as a loser in his yearslong quest to shut down Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company that he bet against, contending it defrauded customers and was a pyramid scheme.

articles.headline: Instagram Takes a Page From Snapchat, and Takes Aim at It, Too
articles.snippet: The new service from Facebook’s photo-sharing app will let people share photos and videos that have a life span of no more than 24 hours with friends who follow them.
articles.abstract: The new service from Facebook’s photo-sharing app will let people share photos and videos that have a life span of no more than 24 hours with friends who follow them.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — For nearly four years, Snapchat has been Facebook’s white whale.

articles.headline: The Case for More Government and Higher Taxes
articles.snippet: The most promising way to improve the nation’s standard of living, some academics argue, is to expand the work of government.
articles.abstract: The most promising way to improve the nation’s standard of living, some academics argue, is to expand the work of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may be hard to remember, but Americans once appreciated the government that serves them. That’s long gone.

articles.headline: Obama Says Republicans Should Withdraw Support for Trump
articles.snippet: During a news conference with the prime minister of Singapore, the president said the Republican nominee was “woefully unprepared to do this job.”
articles.abstract: During a news conference with the prime minister of Singapore, the president said the Republican nominee was “woefully unprepared to do this job.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an extraordinary denunciation of Donald J. Trump’s temperament and competence, President Obama urged leaders of the Republican Party on Tuesday to withdraw their endorsements of Mr. Trump’s candidacy, flatly calling him “unfit to serve” as the nation’s 45th president.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Nick Corasaniti
